dialog.name: properties_setting
dialog.whatsthis: Lists major processes involved in the current design flow.
Lists all the settings associated with the selected process.
Filters the settings displayed for the selected process.
Specifies all the settings for the currently selected process to their default values.
Displays brief definition for the highlighted setting.
Applies and saves any changes you have made and closes this dialog box.
Closes this dialog box without saving any changes you have made.
Applies and saves any changes you have made in this dialog box.
Displays the help contents on this dialog box or detailed description for the highlighted setting.
dialog.description: Allows the use of duplicate modules in your design.
Specifies optimization preference for area reduction over timing delay reduction.
Allows Synplify Pro to reorder the VHDL source files for synthesis.
Controls gated and generated clock conversion.
Enables additional command line options for the Synplify Pro Synthesis process.
(For VHDL designs) Defines how enumerated data types are implemented.
Controls whether the synthesis tool will add I/O buffers into your design.

When this option is set in the strategy, the synthesis tool will NOT duplicate the registers while inferring the address pointers for the RAM during Shift-register inference. By default this option is OFF and the tool will duplicate the address pointer registers to get better performance.

Controls the format of bus names in the EDIF file. Select Standard to use brackets in the names of bus signals as in "bus[1]", which is the current standard for Synplify Pro. Select Legacy to use the older format as in "bus_1".

Controls whether the strategy settings are exported to Synplify Pro during interactive synthesis (opening Synplify Pro through the Tools menu). After opening Synplify Pro, you can change settings in Synplify Pro's interface. This option has no effect with integrated or stand-alone synthesis.
Controls fanout during synthesis. When the specified fanout limit is achieved, logic will be duplicated.
Forces Global Set/Reset Pin usage.
Specifies the global design frequency (in MHz). Nothing in the Value column means "auto" (the default) and Synplify Pro will try to maximize the frequency of the clocks.
Enables or disables the FSM Compiler and controls the use of FSM synthesis for state machines.
Specifies all the paths to the directories which contain the Verilog library files to be included in your design for the project.
Specifies the number of critical timing paths to be reported in the timing report.
Specifies the number of start and end points you want the software to report in the critical path section of the timing report.
Outputs a mapped Verilog or VHDL netlist for post-synthesis simulation.
Enables the pipelining and retiming features to improve design performance.
When this is set to True, the Synplify Pro compiler pushes tristates through objects such as muxes, registers, latches, buffers, nets, and tristate buffers, and propagates the high impedance state.
If a net is driven by a VCC or GND and active drivers, setting this option to True (default) will connect the net to the VCC or GND driver.
When this is set to True (default), the synthesis tool uses resource sharing techniques to optimize area.
Determines whether (True) or not (False) changes inside a compile point can cause the compile point (or top-level) containing it to change accordingly.
Controls whether to forward annotate constraints for I/O ports without explicit user-defined constraints.

When this is set to True (default), Synplify Pro creates a preference (.lpf) file based on the Synopsys Design Constraint (.sdc) file. With this .lpf file, the synthesis constraints will also be applied to the Map Design stage of implementation.
Specifies the Verilog standard used for the project.
When this is set to True, VHDL 2008 is selected as the VHDL standard for the project.
Specifies optimization preference for area reduction over timing delay reduction.
Enables or disables the Precision tool to check array bounds for Verilog input files.
Enables or disables the automatic resource allocation of RAMs.
Enables additional command line options for the Precision Synthesis process.
Controls the gated-clock conversion by Precision RTL Synthesis during the synthesis phase.
Controls whether the synthesis tool will add I/O buffers into your design.
Forces Global Set/Reset Pin usage.
Specifies the global design frequency (in MHz).
Specifies the encoding style to use with the design.

When set to True, tells Precision that for all case statements throughout your design, all relevant conditions are specified. If the default assignment is not used then this option prevents the inference of latches.
Controls whether to ignore RAM read/write collision.
When this is set to True, Precision Synthesis will optimize pipeline registers across hierarchical boundaries.
Specifies the global input delay (in ns) for use with the frequency switch.
Specifies the number of critical timing paths to be reported in the timing report.
Specifies the number of timing paths to be reported in the timing report.
Specifies the global output delay (in ns) for use with the frequency switch.
Outputs a mapped Verilog or VHDL netlist for post-synthesis simulation.
When this is set to True (default), Precision RTL Synthesis creates a preference file and gives it the same name as the module: module_name.prf.

When set to True, tells Precision that for all case statements throughout your design, case conditions are mutually exclusive. This results in a multiplexer implementation instead of a priority encoder.
Controls Precision FSM extraction and re-encoding when Precision needs to create decoding logic.
Setting this to True (default) lets the software report all clock frequencies.
When this is set to True, the timing report will report missing constraints.
When this is set to True (default), the timing report will include timing violations.
When this is set to True (default), the synthesis tool uses resource sharing techniques to optimize area.
Setting this to True (default) causes the advanced retiming algorithms to be run.
When this is set to True, the timing report will show clock domain crossings.
When this is set to True (default), the timing report will show net fanout.
Setting this to True transforms Set/Reset on DFFs to Latches.
Enables or disables the use of safe FSMs.
When this is set to True, Verilog 2001 is selected as the Verilog standard for the project. Otherwise, Verilog 95 will be used.

When set to True, allows the design to keep duplicate modules. LSE issues a warning and uses the last definition of the module. Any previous definitions are ignored. The default is False, which causes an error if there are duplicate modules.
Specifies the maximum number of carry chain cells (CCUs) that get mapped to a single carry chain. Default is 0, which is interpreted as infinite length.
Enables additional command line options for the LSE Synthesis process.
When set to True, synthesis infers safe recovery logic from unreachable states in all the state machines of the design.
When set to True, inferred memory will not use the distributed RAM of the PFUs.
Specifies how DSP modules should be implemented: with DSP resources or with Logic (LUTs).
Specifies the percentage of DSP sites that LSE should try to use.
Specifies EBR utilization target setting in percent of total vacant sites. LSE will honor the setting and do the resource computation accordingly. Default is 100 (in percentage).

When set to True, LSE changes standard gated clocks to forms more effective for FPGAs. Clocks are gated with AND or OR gates to conserve power, but in FPGAs such clocks cause skew and prevent global clock resources from being used. The Fix Gated Clocks option is ignored if the Optimization Goal option is set to Area.
Enables (True) or disables (False) forced use of the global set/reset routing resources. When the value is Auto, the synthesis tool decides whether to use the global set/reset resources.
Specifies the encoding style to use with the design.

Enables or disables the ability to temporarily test IP in a device without an IP license. If enabled, a timer is added to the design that allows unlicensed IP to function for about 4 hours in a device. If disabled, you cannot generate a bitstream if there are any unlicensed IP in the design.

If you set this to True, LSE will produce intermediate encrypted Verilog files. If you supply Lattice with these files, they can be decrypted and analyzed for problems. This option is good for analyzing simulation issues.

Specifies the maximum number of iterations of "for" and "while" loops in the source code. The limit is applied when the loop index is a variable, not when it is a constant. The higher the loop_limit, the longer the run time. The default value is 1950. Setting a higher value may cause stack overflow during some of the optimizations during synthesis. A lower value will be ignored and the default used instead.

Allows you to specify a path (or paths) to locate physical macro files used in a given design. The software will add the specified paths to the list of directories to search when resolving file references. The option can also be used for indicating the directories containing include files that are specified in the RTL design files.
Specifies the maximum fanout setting. LSE will make sure that any net in the design is not exceeding this limit. Default is 1000 fanouts.

Allows you to specify a path (or paths) to locate memory initialization file (.mem) used in a given design. The software will add the specified path(s) to the list of directories to search when resolving file references.
Specifies the MUX style setting, which controls the way the macrogenerator implements the multiplexer macros.
Specifies the number of critical timing paths to be reported in the timing report.
Enables LSE to optimize the design for area, speed, or balanced.
When set to True (default), enables constant propagation to reduce area, where possible. LSE will then eliminate the logic used when constant inputs to logic cause their outputs to be constant.
Sets the type of random access memory globally to distributed, embedded block RAM, or registers.
Specifies the removal of duplicate registers.
Setting this to On removes LOC properties in the synthesized design before building the Native Generic Database (.ngd) file.
If a net is driven by a VCC or GND and active drivers, setting this option to True connects the net to the VCC or GND driver.
When this is set to True (default), the synthesis tool uses resource sharing techniques to optimize area.
Allows you to globally implement ROM architectures using dedicated, distributed ROM, or a combination of the two (Auto).

Specifies the target frequency setting. This frequency applies to all the clocks in the design. If there are some clocks defined in an .ldc file, the remaining clocks will get this frequency setting. When a create_clock constraint is available in an .ldc file, LSE ignores the Target Frequency setting for that clock and uses the value from the create_clock constraint instead.
Turns on (True) or off (False) carry chain implementation for adders. Default is True.
When set to True, LSE uses I/O insertion and GSR.

When True, this option forces the synthesis tool to pack all input and output registers into I/O pad cells based on the timing requirements for the target device family. Auto, the default setting, enables this register packing if Optimization Goal is set to Area. If Optimization Goal is Timing or Balanced, Auto disables register packing.

LSE creates a preference (.lpf) file based on the Synopsys Design Constraint (.sdc) file. (When you use LSE, SDC constraints must be in a Lattice Design Constraints (.ldc) file.) When this option is set to True, the synthesis constraints are also applied to the Map Design stage of implementation.
When this is set to True, VHDL 2008 is selected as the VHDL standard for the project.
Enables EDIF2NGD command line options for the Synplify Translate Design process.
Allows you to set preferences for bus signals in Verilog and VHDL designs that can be honored by LSE, Synopsys Synplify Pro, and Mentor Graphics Precision synthesis tools.

Enables or disables the ability to temporarily test IP in a device without an IP license. If enabled, a timer is added to the design that allows unlicensed IP to function for about 4 hours in a device. If disabled, you cannot generate a bitstream if there are any unlicensed IP in the design.

Allows you to specify a path (or paths) to locate physical macro files used in a given design. The software will add the specified paths to the list of directories to search when resolving file references.

Allows you to specify paths to locate memory initialization files (.mem) used in a given design. Diamond will add the specified paths to the list of directories to search when resolving file references.

Allows you to specify paths to locate native generic object files (.ngo) that define partitions used in the design. Diamond will add the specified paths to the list of directories to search when resolving file references. The partition .ngo files will be loaded and used for replacing the original partition.
Setting this to On removes LOC properties in the synthesized design before building the Native Generic Database (.ngd) file.
Enables additional command line options for the associated process.
Enables or disables the Map Design process to ignore errors in the preference file.
Enables or disables the GSR inferencing.
Directs the I/O register packing.

When this is set to True, the Map Design process will write a Native Circuit Description (.ncd) file even if the device is too small for the design. This .ncd file cannot be used for Place and Route Design, just for you to observe mapping results.
Sets the relative density (of available slices) at which the slices within a device are to be packed, in terms of a percentage of the available slices in the device.
Moves registers across combinational logic to balance timing according to the constraints tSU (INPUT_SETUP), tCO (CLOCK_TO_OUT), and fMAX (FREQUENCY).
When this is set to True, the map report (.mrp) will show where nets in the logical design were mapped in the physical design (NCD).
When this is set to True, the map report (.mrp) will show where symbols in the logical design were mapped in the physical design (NCD).
Allows you to apply timing-driven logic collapsing and optimization to further optimize the critical paths.
Allows you to activate timing driven logic replication.
Allows you to activate timing driven packing of LUT/FF, FF/LUT, and LUT/LUT in the same slice.
Specifies the analysis type.
Lists the auto-generated timing preferences in the TRACE report.
Reports connections not covered by a timing preference.
Reports paths not covered by a timing preference.
When this is set to True, the TRACE report will show full-length component names instead of the truncated names.
Sets the maximum number of unconstrained paths that will be reported. "Unconstrained paths" are those not covered by a timing preference.
Produces a report of paths that could not be analyzed because they are asynchronous loop.
Specifies the type of the timing report.
Configures the route estimation algorithm for pre-route static timing analysis.
Specifies the number of paths to be reported for each timing preference. Enter zero or a grater value.

Controls whether the router will automatically insert extra wires to compensate for hold-time violations on affected registers. Auto hold-time correction has a negative impact on your setup time. If the setup time is more design critical, turn off this option. The default is On.
Balances routing to reduce skews for clock signals that are not assigned to the global clock tree.
Allows you to specify options from the par command without directly using the command line. Type in a string of options without the par command. For example: -exp parPathBased=ON:parHold=1
Enables or disables the congestion-driven placement algorithm.
Enables or disables the congestion-driven routing algorithm.
When set to True, outputs a delay report file (.dly) on each PAR run.
(MachXO3L/LF 9400C/E devices only.) The proper Default Clock Frequency (MHz) must be set before running the Thermal Analysis process. Default setting of 0 will cause an error.
Enables or disables the timing-driven option for the PAR run.
Generates a post-PAR TRACE report (.twr) for each intermediate NCD created by multi-PAR.
Enables or disables the Place and Route Design process to ignore errors in the preference file.
Allows you to specify the node file name for the multi-tasking PAR.
Allows you to apply path-based placement. Path-based placement gives better performance and more predictable results.
Specifies the effort level of the design from 1 (simplest designs) to 5 (most complex designs).
Specifies the cost table to use (from 1-100) to begin the PAR run.
Specifies the maximum number of placement/routing passes (0-100, 0 = run until solved) to be run (regardless of whether they complete) at the Placement Effort Level.
Determines the number (1-100) of best outputs of the Place and Route run to save (defaults to 1).

Specifies how to sort the results of the Place and Route run in the PAR report. Results are sorted first by the number of unrouted connections. Then the results are ranked by timing. Choose whether you want to use the worst-slack value or the timing score to rank the results.
When this is set to True (default), the software removes the contents of the project design directory before Place and Route Design is rerun.
Determines the number of passes to be run for Routing Delay Reduction and Routing Resource Optimization properties. The first delay-based cleanup pass produces the greatest improvement.
Specifies router algorithm.
Determines the maximum number of routing passes the place and route tool takes.
Determines the number of cost-based cleanup passes to run.
Setting this to True prevents the design from being routed. PAR will output a placed, but not routed Native Circuit Description (.ncd) file.

This is a multi-seed PAR option that uses checkpoints for comparing the result of the current placement seed with the results already obtained. A placement seed that is not producing better results will automatically be terminated.
This option allows the user to select between LVCMO12_18 ONLY (default) or LVCMOS_NOT_PERMITTED.

Setting this to True forces the Place and Route Design process to stop as soon as the timing requirement is satisfied. This option has no effect if the "Generate TRACE report for each iteration" option is set to True or if using Run Manager to produce multiple place-and-route runs.
Specifies the analysis type.
Lists the auto-generated timing preferences in the TRACE report.
Reports connections not covered by a timing preference.
Reports paths not covered by a timing preference.
When this is set to True, the TRACE report will show full-length component names instead of the truncated names.
Sets the maximum number of unconstrained paths that will be reported. "Unconstrained paths" are those not covered by a timing preference.
Produces a report of paths that could not be analyzed because they are asynchronous loop.
Specifies the type of the timing report.

Specifies performance grade for hold analysis. This option allows you to override the default m (minimum) performance grade for hold time analysis, which represents faster silicon than the fastest performance grade of the device being targeted.

Specifies performance grade for setup analysis. This option allows you to override the default performance grade which runs setup analysis against the performance grade of the device currently targeted by the project implementation.
Specifies the number of paths to be reported for each timing preference. Enter zero or a grater value.
Controls whether the I/O timing report (.ior) will give an in-depth analysis on all available performance grades or will just produce a summary report on the worst-case performance grade.
When this is set to False, the timing simulation file generation process will not write PUR instance in the Verilog/VHDL backannotation netlist. Then you have to instantiate PUR in the test bench.
When this is set to True, the Timing Simulation process will place X notifiers in the output file on flip-flops with setup and/or hold time violations.
Setting this to True replaces all timing information for back annotation with the minimum timing for all paths.
Distributes routing delays by splitting the signal and inserting buffers. The delay value assigned represents the maximum delay number in picoseconds between each buffer (1000 ps by default).
Adds a prefix to module names to make them unique for multi-chip simulation.
Allows you to select negative setup time and negative hold time for better accuracy.
Retargets back annotation to a different performance grade than the one used to create the Native Circuit Description (.ncd) file.

When this is set to True, the VitalTransport glitch propagation type is used rather than the default OnDetect glitch propagation type. This selection should be used to prevent filtering of a glitch when an input pulse is shorter than the propagation delay..
Specifies the hierarchy separator character which will be used in name generation when the design hierarchy is flattened.
When this is set to False (default), a parameterized netlist will be generated. The parameterized format contains less details, but is more compact in size and memory efficient within the simulator.
Specifies the bitstream addressing mode.
Reverses the order of the bits on a byte-by-byte basis.
When enabled, allows daisy chaining with other devices.
When set to True, generates a bitstream file.
Excludes or includes the "User Electronic Signature Data" field in the JEDEC file.
When enabled, programs the FPGA to drive outputs (not be tristated) during configuration/reconfiguration.
When this is set to true and there is timing error in the Place and Route report file, a dialogue box will display before executing bitstream generation.
Used for testing Master configuration modes.
Controls an internal system bus grant counter that counts the number of HCLK (sysbus clk) cycles that go by before the grant signal is taken away from the master.
Specifies bitstream length.
When this is set to True, the header, or comment string, is not included in the bitstream.
Specifies the type of bitstream to create for an FPGA device.
Controls whether zero frames are written to the output bitstream.
Specifies the type of PROM data to create for an FPGA device.
Controls whether the sysCONFIG readback operation will read from FLASH or SRAM.
When this is enabled, the GLB is targeted during readback.
Controls whether the software will reset all flip-flops before reconfiguring the target FPGA.
The Reset option reinitializes the device when you download a bitstream or JEDEC file. The No Reset option retains the current configuration and allows additional bitstream or JEDEC configuration.
The Reset option reinitializes the device when you download a bitstream or JEDEC file. The No Reset option retains the current configuration and allows additional bitstream or JEDEC configuration.
When this is set to True, the software runs a physical design rule check and saves the output to the Bit Generation report file (.bgn).
Allows you to specify the search path of the auto-configuration file that is located in a directory other than the project directory.
Specifies SPI start address.
Controls whether to use CCLK or a User clock during startup.
Specifies either Reset or NoReset as the system bus clock at reconfiguration.
Specifies either Reset or NoReset as the system bus at reconfiguration.
Sets the order of the TAG memory content of LatticeXP2 devices. Normal is for TAG memories created with Diamond 3.0 or later. Legacy is for TAG memories created with Diamond 2.2 or earlier.
Controls an internal system bus timeout counter. The counter counts the number of HCLK (sysbus clk) cycles that go by while the system bus is in wait states.
Controls the calibration circuit connected to XRES pin.
